com.fluidops.iwb.api
Class ReadDataManagerImpl

java.lang.Object
  com.fluidops.iwb.api.ReadDataManagerImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
ReadDataManager
Direct Known Subclasses:
ReadWriteDataManagerImpl
public class ReadDataManagerImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements ReadDataManager

Data management class for database read access. To avoid unnecessary opening and closing of connections, we do not allow to create arbitrary new instances, but instead provide a static method that can be used to get an instance bound to a certain repository. For each repository, there is exactly one ReadDataManager instance that has associated exactly one repository connection associated.

Author:
msc

          Sparql Query Types, CONSTRUCT subsumes DESCRIBE (both graph types)

          Verify if the connection to the specified repository works, throw a meaningful exception otherwise.

Method Detail

verifyConnection

public static void verifyConnection(org.openrdf.repository.Repository r,
                                    boolean checkWrite)
Verify if the connection to the specified repository works, throw a meaningful exception otherwise. To check for writable, the API method Repository.isWritable() is used.

Parameters:
r -
checkWrite - if true, it is also verified if the repository is writable

closeQuietly

public static <E> void closeQuietly(info.aduna.iteration.CloseableIteration<E,? extends java.lang.Exception> closable)
Close a result iteration quietly, e.g. RepositoryResult

Parameters:
closable -

getDataManager

public static ReadDataManagerImpl getDataManager(org.openrdf.repository.Repository r)
To be used instead of the constructor. Clients do not need to catch RepositoryExceptions any more. Whenever one occurs, this class closes the connection so clients do no longer need to close the connection in the finally block.

Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
Convert a resource into a nice name which can be displayed on the UI, uses internal caching mechanism. If available, uses the rdf:label, if URI use the URI local name, else simply toString for literals, just return the literal itself. The returned string is HTML-encoded, i.e. ready for use in the UI; if you need an unencoded String, call ReadDataManager.getLabel(Value) instead.

sparqlConstruct

public org.openrdf.query.GraphQueryResult sparqlConstruct(java.lang.String query,
                                                          boolean resolveNamespaces,
                                                          org.openrdf.model.Value resolveValue,
                                                          boolean infer)
                                                   throws org.openrdf.repository.RepositoryException,
                                                          org.openrdf.query.MalformedQueryException,
                                                          org.openrdf.query.QueryEvaluationException
Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
Evaluates a SPARQL CONSTRUCT query on the DataManager's connection and returns the result in form of a GraphQueryResult. Namespace prefixes used in the query are resolved using the namespaces that are currently registered with the namespace service. In addition, the pattern "??" is replaced by the URI given by resolveURI. infer determines whether inferencing should be applied or not.

prepareQuery

public org.openrdf.query.Query prepareQuery(java.lang.String query,
                                            boolean resolveNamespaces,
                                            org.openrdf.model.Value resolveValue,
                                            boolean infer)
                                     throws org.openrdf.repository.RepositoryException,
                                            org.openrdf.query.MalformedQueryException,
                                            java.lang.IllegalAccessException
Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
Prepares a SPARQL query on the DataManager's connection. Namespace prefixes used in the query are resolved using the namespaces that are currently registered with the namespace service. In addition, the pattern "??" is replaced by the URI given by resolveURI, and $user$ are replaced by the user URI. Query timeout is set as defined by Config#queryTimeout This method allows to create Tuple, Graph and Boolean queries, i.e. all kinds of update queries are explicitly forbidden. In such case an IllegalAccessException is thrown.

Specified by:
prepareQuery in interface ReadDataManager
Parameters:
query - a valid SPARQL query
resolveNamespaces - flag to enable resolution of namespace prefixes in the query
resolveValue - the value to use for "??" in the query, can be null
infer - boolean flag to indicate inference
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalAccessException - if the query type is not allowed
org.openrdf.repository.RepositoryException
org.openrdf.query.MalformedQueryException

guessValueForPredicate

public org.openrdf.model.Value guessValueForPredicate(java.lang.String name,
                                                      org.openrdf.model.URI predicate,
                                                      boolean preferURI)
Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
The requested subject may be either - a local name in the default namespace, - a prefixed URI, or - a literal. The method uses range information for the given predicate as well as namespace information to distinguish between these three types. Via perferURI it can be specified whether (in case of no schema information) preferably a URI should be returned instead of a literal

Specified by:
guessValueForPredicate in interface ReadDataManager

getContext

public Context getContext(org.openrdf.model.URI contextURI,
                          boolean refreshCacheBeforeLookup)
Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
Returns the contexts associated to the given URI in the given repository using the cache. The refresh parameter can be used to enforce cache refresh; it everything is working fine, it should not be used (which means, if we do not forget to trigger cache refresh when data is updated). Method also updates the cache, i.e. stores the element if it is missing.

Specified by:
getContext in interface ReadDataManager

getContext

public Context getContext(org.openrdf.model.URI contextURI)
Description copied from interface: ReadDataManager
Returns the meta information for the given context in the given repository using the cache. No refresh is enforced (it should not be necessary, though, so this is probably the method you want to use). Method also updates the cache, i.e. stores the element if it is missing.

Specified by:
getContext in interface ReadDataManager

appendToStmtList

public static boolean appendToStmtList(java.util.List<org.openrdf.model.Statement> res,
                                       java.lang.String subject,
                                       org.openrdf.model.URI predicateURI,
                                       java.lang.String object,
                                       boolean objectAsURI)
Append the values to the list of statements.

Parameters:
res - The list of statements where the result is appended
subject - The subject of the statement to create, will be used to generate a URI
predicateURI - The predicate URI
object - The object of the statement to create, will be used to generate either a URI or a literal based on the last param
objectAsURI - If set true, the object string will be created into a URI, otherwise a literal will be created
Returns:
If no valid statement can be constructed the method has no effect and returns false, otherwise true

parseValue

public static org.openrdf.model.Value parseValue(java.lang.String s)
Parses a value according to (a slightly simplified) version of the SPARQL GraphTerm specification (cf. W3C SPARQL Grammar "[45] Graph Term"). In contrast to the W3C, we do not support blank nodes and no NIL; further the double datatype (with exponent notation) is not supported and we assume there is no escaping in literals. Except for that, the standard should be matched quite well. If we need better standard compliance here, it would probably be best to integrate the W3C EBNF grammar and use an existing EBNF parser, but for now this is good enough.

parseURI

public static org.openrdf.model.URI parseURI(java.lang.String s)
Parses a full URI or a prefixed URI, dependent on the first non-whitespace character.

Parameters:
s -

Parse a full URI like ""

Returns:

parseLiteral

public static org.openrdf.model.Literal parseLiteral(java.lang.String s)
Parse a literal like "test", "test"@de", or "test"^^xsd:string.
